body.name: A Rambling Man: A Classic Western Adventure (Lucas Cain Book 1)
body.description: Bestselling author Robert Vaughan is back with another riveting adventure in this 2024 Independent Press Award Winner—sure to please fans of all ages.Captured in the last year of the Civil War, Lucas Cain is a POW in the infamous Andersonville prison. There, he learns how to survive the cruelty of the Confederate guards and the perfidy of others who are prisoners themselves.When the war ends, he and almost 1,500 others crowd aboard the riverboat Sultana, which has a capacity of just under 400 passengers. When tragedy strikes, Lucas finds himself further adrift. Returning home to Cape Girardeau, Missouri, he becomes a police officer, where he finds an unexpected love interest in a journalist who works for the Cape Girardeau newspaper.But as Lucas finds himself no longer able to remain in Cape Girardeau, he begins a western drift. Rambling without a specific destination and becoming a bounty hunter, he ventures into the untamed West…where the call of the open road just may lead him to wander forever. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
reviews.reviewText: My first time reading character and author, absolutely loved the story and subplots, and all the other characters. Look forward to next book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Lucas Caine, a rambling man.
reviews.reviewText: The first half of the book rated 5 stars. I was a little disappointed in the second half and it turned into 4 stars. I was very captivated in the beginning. The Andersonville prison life, escaping the boat explosion, and the many adventures of Lucas Cain getting the bad guy. At the end I didn’t like the idea that they had a court, judge, and jury, when Lucas Cain was not guilty, and there was plenty of evidence that he wasn’t. The sheriff investigated and found him innocent. Was this just “book filler?” That part of the story wasted time and wasn’t going anywhere. The prosecutor in the vest—what was his story. He was too stupid wasting the town’s money and time! Too bad he left Sue Ellen and didn’t find love. Maybe in the next book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great start to a story Series with Lucas Cain
reviews.reviewText: Cain’s back story begins in the horrid conditions of the Confederate Andersonville Prison and once released, launches Lucas as a Rambling man working odd jobs as an unpaid Deputy Sheriff who earns his living in various frontier towns as a successful Bounty Hunter. With the dual personality traits of fairness and helping the downtrodden, when he stops in Higton, he is swept into a local dispute over land rights for a railroad extension. That’s when an honest Sheriff, a widow and her beautiful daughter join with Lucas to solve the threats to local land owners. A page turner you cannot put down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Rambling Man: A Classic Western Adventure
reviews.reviewText: This was absolutely wonderful, I could not put it down, so I didn't! Definitely a must read, this one book you will love, there is so much excitement, joy, lots of drama and mysteries solved, lots of action packed scenes throughout this book! Every page is a absolutely amazing story and there's something about this story that will keep you turning those pages! So don't miss this one, not kidding!🤠📚🎭🐝🎶

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars enjoyed the story
reviews.reviewText: Lucas Cain’s life starts out badly as a confederate prisoner of the Civil War. Unbelievable atrocities as a surviving prisoner with his best friend Dan. At the end of the war their stories continue. Lucas becomes a licensed “bounty hunter”, suffers tragic personal consequences and becomes the “rambling man”. Traveling westward through many small towns encountering both good and bad people.Story is well written and believable.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed this story. It wasn’t much like what I have read but it was good. The plot was clear and they did solve the mystery but it was silly in the end. I was disappointed in its ending.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Slow start; then sputters along
reviews.reviewText: I read the author's Grizzly Killer series last year and it was really good. So I looked forward to this book. But it was a bit like my first car, took forever to get started and then just kind of sputtered along.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Review of “Rambling Man”
reviews.reviewText: Robert Vaughn doesn’t disappoint his readers with this great story. It begins in the Civil War at the battle of Shiloh, and Sgt Lucas Cain and many of his company are captured by by Confederate forces and transported to Andersonville prison for the duration of the war. Thousands died in this hell hole due to abysmal conditions and treachery of some of their fellow soldiers and their evil captors. When Lucas is finally freed, he journeys back home with his friend Dan and thousands of others. A great story filled with some of the horrors of Andersonville, and the integrity and fortitude of Lucas Cain and his joys and heartaches.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 13, 2023
reviews.reviewText: If you like this author this is him back to his best.

reviews.reviewTitle: “You... you done killed me, he said”
reviews.reviewText: A Rambling Man is an ongoing ramble of small episodes with repetitive narratives that culminate in one much larger final chapter! The settings lack accurate historical details in the small western towns visited, the many saloons (where considerable actions occurs ) or even the shops or businesses that feature in the narrative. Meanwhile even the landscapes are virtually ignored! Thus the novel does not develop the mood, atmosphere or complexity that the better western texts achieve.
